## Cleaning the data
```{r}
cancer = read.csv("wisc.csv")
cancer$id = NULL
cancer$diagnosis = as.factor(cancer$diagnosis)
str(cancer)
summary(cancer)
```

## Getting the data ready for analysis
```{r}
# Using model.matrix to convert all the factors to dummy variables
# We are converting all of the factors into dummy variables as the input into knn has to be numeric

cancermm <- as.data.frame(model.matrix(~.-1,cancer))

# Randomize the rows in the data (shuffling the rows)
set.seed(0)
cancer_random <- cancermm[sample(nrow(cancermm)),]

#Normalize the data
normalize <- function(x) {
  return ((x - min(x)) / (max(x) - min(x)))
}

# we are going to normalize everything 
cancer_norm <- as.data.frame(lapply(cancer_random, normalize))
str(cancer_norm)
```

## Getting Train and Test Samples

```{r}
# Selects 10000 random rows for test data
test_set <- sample(1:nrow(cancer_norm), 285) 
# Depending on R-version and computer, different rows may be selected. 
# If that happens, results are different. 

# Create a train set and test set
#First the predictors 
train <- cancer_norm[-test_set,]
test <- cancer_norm[test_set,]

train_labels <- cancer_norm[-test_set, "diagnosisM"]
test_labels <- cancer_norm[test_set, "diagnosisM"]
```

## THE LOG MODEL

```{r}
str(train)
```


```{r}
logmodel = glm(diagnosisM ~., data = train, family = "binomial")

log_cancer <- predict(logmodel, test, type= "response")
summary(log_cancer)
log_cancer_diagnosis <- ifelse(log_cancer < 0.2,0,1)
CrossTable(x=test$diagnosisM, y=log_cancer_diagnosis, prop.chisq=FALSE)
confusionMatrix(as.factor(log_cancer_diagnosis), as.factor(test$diagnosisM), positive = "1")

summary(logmodel)
```
